I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will provide policy recommendations 
and  technical  guidance  for  disaster  risk  management  (DRM)  based  on  natural  hazard 
characteristics, exposure, and physical and socioeconomic vulnerabilities.1 Specifically, the TA will 
develop frameworks, build capacity, provide technical guidance, and define cost-effective options 
for DRM in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The TA will foster regional partnerships among 
the PRC and neighboring countries on improving disaster preparedness and resilience. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the indicative country operations business plan for the PRC, 2021–
2023.2 The TA is aligned with the country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2021–2025 (strategic 
priority 2) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB),3 and supports all seven operational priorities of 
ADB's Strategy 2030.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Because of its size and environmental diversity, the PRC is highly exposed to a range of 
frequent natural hazards affecting a wide geographic area. The combined impact of climate change 
and urbanization poses mounting pressure on society, as the exposure of people and infrastructure 
to natural hazards is increasing, outpacing the decrease in vulnerability. Women, children, and the 
vulnerable are disproportionately affected by disasters. Disasters undermine efforts to eradicate 
poverty, as disasters can perpetuate the cycle of poverty and impair households’ development 
prospects in the long run. Capacity for DRM is inadequate. Some regions still lack the capability 
to establish a disaster risk assessment tool. Others have not systematically explored measures to 
reduce disaster risk, such as urban planning, urban regeneration, early warning systems, disaster 
risk financing tools, and protection mechanisms, and their cost-effectiveness remains untested.5 
Considering the high potential demand for investment in disaster risk reduction, priorities need to 
be established, in part based on cost-effectiveness. Flood storage and detention areas (FSDAs), 
which are vital in flood mitigation, face a serious dilemma because of local socioeconomic 
development.6 Lastly, the capacity for early response and recovery still needs improvement to 
prevent deaths and reduce economic losses. Therefore, an integrated framework for cost-effective 
 
1  In the TA, disasters refer to those caused by natural hazards, including geophysical, meteorological, climatological, 
and hydrological hazards. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 8 June 2021. The TA was proposed 
as a cluster TA with four subprojects, now combined into one TA for efficiency gains. Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous 
Region (GZAR) and Fujian Province in the original proposals are retained under this TA. 
3 ADB. 2021. Country Partnership Strategy: People's Republic of China, 2021–2025—Toward High-Quality, Green 
Development. Manila. 
4  The seven operational priorities are (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities; (ii) accelerating 
progress in gender equality; (iii) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing 
environmental sustainability; (iv) making cities more livable; (v) promoting rural development and food security; (vi) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity; and (vii) fostering regional cooperation and integration (ADB. 
2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila). 
5  Cost-effectiveness analysis refers to the unit costs of achieving outcomes of interest to local policy makers (e.g., 
strengthening resilience). In cases where local policy makers have an interest in multiple outcomes that can best be 
harmonized as economic values, effectiveness will refer to benefits, so that the approach is a cost–benefit analysis. 
For simplicity, “cost–effectiveness analysis” is interpreted to include “cost–benefit analysis” in this document.  
6  FSDAs can help attenuate flood peaks by holding excessive runoff, thereby reducing damage in downstream areas. 
The design of FSDA features and operational modalities depends on hydrological, geological, and socioeconomic 
characteristics of the river basin. Currently, the functionality of FSDAs is challenged by local socioeconomic 
development which result in higher exposure of assets and humans to floods but is limited because of the nature of 
FSDAs. Socioeconomic development in FSDAs is not resilient: asset and socioeconomic losses are high and recovery 
after floods is slow.

2 
DRM, including understanding of disaster risks, solutions for disaster risk reduction, and early 
response and recovery, is required to support sustainable development. 
 
4.  The National Comprehensive Disaster Prevention and Mitigation Plan, 2016–2020 (i) 
reiterates the complexity of disasters and the weaknesses in disaster risk prevention, mitigation, 
and rescue; (ii) promotes shared responsibility mechanisms between central government and local 
authorities in decision-making; (iii) supports insurance and other market-based solutions; and (iv) 
promotes international collaboration.7 The 2017 Pilot Work for Climate Adaptive City Construction 
highlights the need for urban adaptability to extreme weather events and capacity for disaster 
monitoring and early warning.8 The PRC launched the first national comprehensive disaster risk 
survey in  2020,  headed  by  the  Ministry of  Emergency  Management,  to  understand  hazard 
exposure and to assess the capacity of local government, society, and community in disaster 
prevention, mitigation, and rescue. In response to government guidelines, local authorities have 
developed customized plans for DRM and climate change adaptation, such as the Guangxi 
Zhuang Autonomous Region (GZAR) Climate Change Adaptation Plan, 2016–2020.9 
 
5.  The TA will build on the government's efforts and partner with four executing agencies. The 
TA will (i) improve the understanding of disaster risk in GZAR;10 (ii) develop solutions for disaster 
resilience strengthening, including (a) recommendations and measures to reduce disaster risk in 
GZAR; (b) an FSDA model customized to local socioeconomic development and climate change; 
and (c) resilient city development, including urban planning, construction, and management, with 
a focus on smart technologies, operation, and financing; (iii) conduct research on rapid action 
teams for flood and typhoon response in Fujian Province;11 and (iv) foster regional collaboration 
on investment in resilience. The TA will cover a wide geographic area encompassing provinces 
and cities at various levels of economic development, which provide a basis to assess the cost-
effectiveness of various options for investment in resilience.12 The TA will foster institutional 
coordination among the four implementing agencies, strengthening institutional cooperation and 
disaster risk governance. The TA will generate regional public goods by promoting knowledge and 
experience sharing among the PRC and selected disaster-prone countries,13 and by establishing 
bilateral and multilateral frameworks to promote investment in resilience, supported by the Greater 
Mekong Subregion Urban Development Strategic Framework, 2015–2022 and the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 2030 Strategic Framework.14

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: disaster risk prevention and mitigation 
improved (footnote 7), and international cooperation and global partnership for disaster risk 
reduction strengthened.15 The TA will have the following outcome: readiness to invest in disaster 
risk reduction improved.16 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Disaster risk identification and assessment improved. The output will help 
GZAR assess disaster risk in all its dimensions: vulnerability; exposure of people and assets; 
hazard characteristics; and impact, including disaggregated impact analysis by age, income, and 
gender. The output will carry out the following activities: (i) collecting and reviewing historical data 
on hazards and exposure of people and assets, identifying people and assets at risk, and 
parameterizing vulnerability of human capital and infrastructure in GZAR and, at a more granular 
level, in Wuzhou; (ii) creating a disaster risk assessment index system; and (iii) developing a 
disaster risk assessment tool to estimate disaggregated statistics on disaster losses. The tool can 
help in understanding how a specific group of assets or people (such as women and the poor) are 
affected by hazards, allowing for identification of priorities for investment in resilience. The tool will 
be shared in areas covered by the other outputs, and training will be provided to government 
officials to improve their understanding of disaster risk assessment. 
 
8.  Output  2:  Solutions  to  strengthen  disaster  resilience  proposed.  The  output  will 
develop measures for disaster risk reduction, including (i) hazard exposure control; (ii) vulnerability 
reduction; (iii) early warning systems; and (iv) innovative market-based solutions, including (a) 
mechanisms  to  increase  private  sector  participation  and  risk  sharing;  and  (b)  protection 
mechanisms for all the affected—people; social and physical infrastructure; and the productive 
sector, including micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. The measures will be integrated into 
the disaster risk assessment tool developed under output 1 to assess their cost-effectiveness, 
using scenario analyses, where gender-, age-, and poverty-inclusive, cost-effective disaster risk 
reduction  measures  can  be  identified.  The  output  consists  of  three  components  under  the 
responsibility of three implementing agencies. Building on the results from output 1, output 2a will 
develop disaster risk reduction measures and policy recommendations for identified risk areas and 
draft a report on a GZAR disaster risk reduction strategy. Output 2b will analyze current conditions, 
including construction, management, and operation of national FSDAs, and recommend FSDA 
construction  and  development  models  customized  to  local  socioeconomic  development  and 
climate change, without compromising their functionality. Output 2c will support the development 
of an urban resilience evaluation method and index system and identify measures for disaster risk 
reduction throughout the whole urban life cycle. Based on hazard characteristics, exposure, and 
vulnerability, customized disaster risk reduction measures will be designed for Wuzhou. 
 
9.  Output 3: Research on rapid action teams for flood and typhoon response produced. 
The output will develop a modernized model for rapid action teams and help ensure the functioning 
of critical infrastructure affected during or after a disaster by conducting research on rapid action 
teams for flood and typhoon response in Fujian Province. The output will carry out the following 
activities: (i) analyzing the current conditions and international best practices on rapid action teams

in terms of team composition, capacity, contingency planning, duties, standardized operational 
practice, equipment, budget, and management; (ii) conducting a gap analysis; (iii) developing 
recommendations for organizational arrangement, resource management, and response efficiency; 
(iv) providing policy recommendations to local government authorities on the rapid action teams’ 
support  for  the  early  response;  and  (v)  providing  training  or  workshops  to  strengthen  the 
partnership between the public and private sectors, including civil society organizations. 
 
10.  Output 4: Regional collaboration on investing in disaster resilience promoted. The 
output will strengthen regional collaboration and partnerships on DRM between and among the 
PRC  and  selected  disaster-prone  countries.17 Bilateral  and  multilateral  disaster  resilience–
strengthening frameworks will be developed, under which the following activities will be carried out: 
(i) sharing innovative technology and nonsensitive data; (ii) establishing city-to-city partnerships 
for disaster-resilient city development; (iii) drafting a road map for multi-hazard monitoring and 
early warning systems; and (iv) drafting disaster-specific action plans for disaster response to 
transboundary hazards. At least one regional workshop on knowledge sharing, including on 
gender-, poverty-, and age-inclusive investment in resilience, will be organized, with women 
making up at least 30% of participants. TA findings and workshop feedback will be summarized in 
a knowledge product and published through ADB dissemination channels. 
 
11.  Innovative features. Innovative features of the TA include (i) inclusiveness of major 
stakeholders to provide integrated solutions for DRM, with improved institutional arrangements 
and disaster risk governance; (ii) tailored solutions for DRM considering geographic and economic 
heterogeneity and the local impact of climate change, rather than one solution for all; (iii) a cost-
effectiveness assessment approach for decision makers in their deliberation of various disaster 
risk reduction measures; (iv) bilateral and multilateral frameworks under which a variety of activities 
will be conducted to promote investment in resilience between and among the PRC and selected 
disaster-prone  countries,  with  potential  for  lending  opportunities  or  innovative  products  and 
services for regional DRM; and (v) collaboration with existing TA projects across ADB to cross-
support project design and implementation through shared databases, consolidated approaches 
and methodologies, and lessons learned.18 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,500,000, of which $1,040,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources), and $320,000 will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Fund.19 The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, office supplies, information and documents relevant for the preparation and
